headline: Trump vs. Biden: Battle rages between president and former vice president
subHeadline: President Trump focuses fire on 'sleepy' Joe Biden as the Biden campaign lays low with few public events; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: Well, there is a Goldilocks temperature.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: Not since the prom. Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They have lower skin temperatures and yet we must pretend at all costs, especially in the media, that sex differences are fabricated by a sexist culture.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Sometimes people are cheap, like in New England, and they don't want to have high heating bills, like my parents, so they keep it at like 64 in December and then it freezes everybody and then they make actually make fires. They make fires in the house.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.sentences: Yes, I don't see gender.

utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: I choose my own adventure and go to the gym. "One More Thing" is up next, lucky for all of us. Stay right here.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Time now for "One More Thing". Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.sentences: What was your most memorable experience with law enforcement?

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, PANELIST
utterances.sentences: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, he didn't.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Swear to god. It was Michigan.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: I don't believe that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I swear to god.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, so Gutfeld said that I was a bold-faced liar. Guess what Gutfeld, I got a Facebook message from the police officer, Lieutenant Bob Latent (ph).

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, Bobby.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And he told me tell Greg, my employer can't touch me now, because I'm retired. All right? And the county magistrate even had the picture hung up in her office. All right. So Bob thanks for reaching out. There were are together in Michigan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, geez, please.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But other police officers, please don't get the idea - I might have a heart attack, if I got pulled over.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, my goodness.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. So another Gutfeld Monologues. Throw up the little thing there. It's going to be another great show, Tom Shillue, July 20th at the Paramount Theater, Asbury Park, New Jersey. I hope you guys will come.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, fine.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: Great theater.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, it is a great theater. The Gutfeld Monologues, go to ggutfeld.com to buy tickets. They're going to sell out rather fast. All right, now it's time for something new? "Greg It's Just A Doughnut News" OK. So Hostess - put up this Hostess tweet. This really got my chow. All right, I don't even know what that means.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: That's a phrase.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It says "New Jumbo Donettes for breakfast individually wrapped so you can throw one in your satchel and go". OK. Jumbo Donettes is a doughnut.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: When you enlarge something that is miniature, it becomes normal size, so don't call it Jumbo Donettes. Call it a damn doughnut, because that's what it is. It's just a doughnut.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Doughnut singles.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Doughnut singles. I'm so tired of the lies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I like the idea with the packaging.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You do?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's really smart.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Doughnut singles, sounds like a bar you would go to.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All you can eat Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Doughnut singles, a dating club.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK. So I had the pleasure maybe sitting a dog named Spike. That might have seen him around Fox News.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So he's the yellow lab there. He is a companion dog. Well, he is in training, OK. So he is the dog of my producer Jennifer Williams. She had a little procedure done this weekend, so he came with us for five days and was fun having the two dogs. Now he has different rules from Jasper. Like, he can't get on the furniture. He can't have any human food. But we all worked - we worked it out. He had a little vacation. There's Peter with him at the beach. It was a lot of fun.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Were those rollback scarfs on, and they loved that. That's the lighthouse toy. That did not last long after - there's Jasper had enough of all of that. But it was really funny in canine companions. They're going to get a good dog in him. He goes to intensive training on August 9th, so just a couple of more months, so it's been fun to have him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Does he have any outstanding loans?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, I think he's going to be just fine. He's little - we have loaned our hearts. Juan?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's gross.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right, so what's the difference between a tadpole and a salamander? Well, granddad found out this Memorial Day weekend on a family trip to the Blue Ridge Mountains, West Virginia. My daughter who's on the Board of the National Park Trust took us to George Washington National Forest.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: On the trip the grandkids decided to scoop up little animals with their bare hands from the edge of the pond. So when I said hurt the tadpoles, they scream pop up those are salamanders, you idiot. Here I am with Eli (ph), at the edge of the pond. There was also time for making a fire. Here are Morgan and Raffy (ph) taken the lead on getting the fire going. And here I am with my wife against the beautiful backdrop of what you remember this, John Denver famously described as, "Almost Heaven West Virginia".

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You went to a George Washington Park?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. No, that's when we--

utterances.sentences: Kennedy bring us home.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: Absolutely, right. There are three things that I love.

utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.sentences: The national anthem.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: That man is a patriot, the poise, the control. He served as a medic in the 114th General Hospital Unit in Kidderminster England during World War II.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.sentences: He is actually -- he's actually running against --

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Kennedy, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is “The Five.” The road to 2020 looking like a good one for the president, three new projection models predict Trump will win re-election, that's according to a former Obama administration official, Steven Ratner saying the combination of a strong economy and being the incumbent currently point to a win for Trump. And as the race to the White House continues to heat up, the president not letting up on his attacks on Joe Biden. While overseas, Trump ripping the former vice president for his role in the 1994 crime bill, critics say that legislation led to the mass incarceration for African-American, quote, anyone associated with the 1994 crime bill will not have a chance of being elected. In particular, African-Americans will not be able to vote for you. I, on the other hand, was responsible for criminal justice reform which has tremendous support and help fix the bad 1994 bill. But the road to 2020 could prove difficult for Biden. The Washington Post calling out his campaign strategy which is apparently not doing a lot of campaigning. Quote, the light public schedule reflects the unique position of his campaign. Advisors say with near universal name recognition high favorability ratings among Democrats, the former VP doesn't need to introduce himself to voters like nearly every other candidate. And as the leader in early polls, he can attract media attention without splashy events. Oh, but how long, Greg, can you do that? Does a lack of campaigning eventually catch up to you if you don't look like you are really hungry for it?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.utterance: Hiding Biden. New nickname, hiding Biden. This have not work for Hillary. Remember, they were keeping Hillary, you know, in a freezer. You know, they had her powered down. And then they would charge her and send her out and then, you know, nothing would happen. Look, this is like three segments in one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK, first the polls. This is Ratner is a sneaky little skimmer. This is all hands on deck approach, like telling people that Trump is gonna win, Trump is gonna win, so you better not be complacent because that's what happened with Hillary. So they don't want people to get complacent, so they're not going to play down the Democrats positive polls and play up any Republican or Trump poll to do that. I could talk about the crime bill, but I -- it's -- you can't throw the baby out with the bath water. There's some good stuff in that crime bill and Biden did a good job on it. Trump is coming lately to that stuff and saying that he's, you know, for criminal reform which he has -- but -- this is a new time for Republicans because it used to be -- there're now four housemen after them. It used to be media, academia and entertainment industry. Those were the three groups that were coming after Republicans all the time. They would paint you -- they would say that if you didn't vote Democrat you weren't cool. That was four decades. You were a dork if you weren't a Democrat. Now you can add the fourth horseman which is social media. And that's arguably the most powerful of the four. So now you have four groups that are coming after you, and social media will do it in different ways by playing up positive stuff for the Democrats on their platforms, and playing down positive stuff for Trump on their platforms and you won't even know it. So that's going to be a new hurdle. The other new thing is about -- you have is you have a president who's now a heavyweight contender defending his belt. That's what Trump is. He's Ali defending his belt which means he's going to be trash talking all the way to the end. I just addressed four topics for you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You did a very good job.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sorry about that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I want to ask you, Juan, in the 2016 primary, one of the most effective attacks and weapons that Bernie Sanders had against Hillary Clinton was the crime bill. So it's almost sort of strange to now have the President of the United States trying to use the crime bill against Joe Biden.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.utterance: I think it is strange. I think it's strange because to go with Greg's analogy if this is Muhamad Ali defending the belt, he just dropped his hands because everybody is gonna say, ah, Mr. President, what about you and the Central Park 5, people that you wanted executed who were later exonerated. That's how vicious and angry you were in terms of crime. And Greg picks up another good point which is, hey, wait a second, I thought lots of conservatives, in fact, liked the crime bill, and thought that, in fact, putting more people -- and I will say, you know what? It's not fair to Greg. It's not just conservatives. There're a lot of people in the black community, the majority of the black caucus in Congress --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- pushed for that crime bill.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You have to put yourself back in the time --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You had the crack epidemic.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right. But now you have people out of time, and I think Trump is, you know, kind of trying to imagine people out of context who don't have that memory just jumping on Joe Biden. But I don't think it's gonna work with most Democrats. It might work with some on the far-left, the Black Lives Matter and the like. And people who've written books about mass incarceration which is an issue. But I'm not sure that they're going to say, oh, yeah, as a result of Joe Biden's mistake with the crime bill, I'm voting Trump? I just don't see --

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.utterance: But this is where Trump is a different candidate because he'll hit Biden from the left on something like crime. He hits him from the left on something like trade or foreign intervention or drug pricing. Then when he's all dizzy because he's not used to handling it that way, he'll come from the hard-right on immigration or hard-right on taxes. It's an unorthodox fighting style that a non- traditional candidate isn't used to defending against. And I don't think Biden has the political dexterity to handle those types of attacks. He's old, he's rusty, and he's so traditional. He'll be overwhelmed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, we'll see. But -- you know what I would say for Trump on this, I think -- I haven't seen a Democrat yet who's able to repeat which is the magic sauce for Democrats, which is you get blacks, Latinos, and immigrants and women together.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, that was the Obama coalition and I don't think Biden has the juice to reenact that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We'll see.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Kennedy, do you think that Biden right now is creating an illusion of safety for Democrats? And -- his crowds aren't that big, but his numbers are really, really high.

utterances.speaker: LISA KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, HOST
utterances.utterance: I understand the strategy because he doesn't want to put himself out there and make a bunch of unforce gaffes before the debates while the field is so vast, because while the field is this big he's got so many people coming after him. And if he just lays low and rests on his moral and every once in a while emerges to talk about the good old days of the Obama-Biden presidency and era, he's fine doing that for a little while. He is just biding his time while they're hiding Biden. But I do --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You ain't lying.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: I do think that opens him up to a number of attacks to Jesse's point. And my problem with the crime bill is it took an entire generation, particularly men of color, and showed that they were disposable and not redeemable. And that's the problem with it. And I can't believe it's taken 25 years to right that course. And, you know, we're having the most bizarre conversation with actors leading it that you never wouldn't imagine. You wouldn't imagine that some people see Trump as a hard-core conservative, that he is the one leading the discussion on criminal justice reform which would have been such --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But that's how it works, right? You always -- you always trust the hard liner to do the soft line, right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right. And also you couldn't even have this conversation if it was 1994. Like without the crime bill and the results you would not be actually having the conversation of was that too much.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You could create -- the crime bill could have created, you can argue this and disagree with it. But you can argue that crime bill decreased crime in such a manner that we can now sit here and entertain that it was wrong.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well -- yeah, you could.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: When we talk about these things going forward, I hope it changes the discussion. And I hope we talk about unintended consequences. And that's why, you know, people get really frustrated when we talk about socialism which is it's filled with some wonderful intentions, but the bad that can come of it in the exact same way could be so destructive and long lasting, and I hope that's what leads our political conversation there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think people are sensitive especially on the crime bill front, so I think you're on to it. I just want to get back to where Dana started this segment, which is to say you get people saying Trump has an advantage. I'm kind of surprised that anyone doesn't think that the incumbent --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Always.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- would have an advantage. I mean, I think it's only twice in the last 50 years --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Since World War II only two president have not won re-election.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. So he's got that. Plus, he, you know, it seems to me if you think about it, you know, he -- it's not that it's insurmountable. Let me just not confuse anybody. I'm not trying to play games of the kind of - - I was -- Ratner was accused of. I think Ratner is based on this on a economic model. I think if Trump, in fact, was just based on economics, we would be a very popular president, but he's not. It's because he says things like the craziness he said over in Japan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But a lot of the Democrats don't watch Fox News, they don't travel to red America, they don't read -- to a talk radio, and they thought for 2 years the president is some Russian impostor. So when they read this in the morning and they got their coffee and they spit it out. They're looking for a landslide victory here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A landslide, oh.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: But it also goes to show that resistance breath compliancy. That we hate him so much, he has to go because we hate him. And that circular logic and that's not always the most effective. So now you have someone smart enough to go, oh, maybe if we talk about how great Trump is doing that would actually drive some movement --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Also there's a long way to go, 12 months in fact. All right, big day in federal court for Michael Avenatti, the latest on his back-to-back arraignments when we return.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It wasn't a good day to be Michael Avenatti, the embattled attorney facing two separate arraignments in federal court here in New York involving multiple charges. First, he pleads not guilty to allegedly stealing nearly 300 grand from Stormy. He then also pleads not guilty to charges that he tried to extort up to $25 million from Nike. Here what he told reporters outside the courtroom this afternoon.

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL AVENATTI, LAWYER
utterances.utterance: For over 20 years I have represented David versus Goliath across this nation in many courthouses just like this. I am now facing the fight of my life against the ultimate Goliath, the Trump administration. I am confident that when a jury of my peers passes judgment on my conduct that justice will be done and I will be fully exonerated.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. And he faces I think 400 years. So one of the things -- you don't need to put up the text on the screen, one of his defenses is he wants to investigate the investigators. He wants to know how this whole thing shook out.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It got a certain ring to it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I wonder where he got that from.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: A certain ring to it. You know, he got a very busy day today and I think that he should enjoy it, make the most of it, because if he's going to be in jail for 400 years then he won't have that many busy days going forward. I think perhaps a jury of his peers will let him go. However, the jury of his legal peers they look very -- they frown very much on stealing from you clients. Like that's a number one thing, should not ever steal from your client.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What do you think Stormy is thinking right about now?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is she thinking? You know, I love that he says he defends David from Goliath but he left out steals from Goliath -- David afterwards. He said -- every day he keeps saying I look forward to being vindicated. In what? A court of law which he denied Kavanaugh. The fact is you have to keep looking forward to everyday to being vindicated, maybe look at your own lifestyle, that's all you do. My favorite defense was Brian Stelter's defense of having Stelter -- I mean, having --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I didn't see that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Having --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Avenatti.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Creepy porn lawyer on. He said, well, you know, he's in the news. He's on like cable news, so of course we put him on. So basically he's saying that because we put him on CNN, we're going to put him on CNN. That's like saying, you know, I beat the cat because my previous cat beatings made it acceptable to beat the cat. No logic there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We haven't heard a lot (INAUDIBLE), Kennedy, from the media for putting this guy on. You'd think there would be some sort of self- examination. You know, what did we get wrong?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Well, you think there would be better vetting processes because I spoke to a reporter last week who very easily dug up some of the questionable business dealings that Avenatti have had for years. And, of course, Avenatti went after this journalist and threatened him with legal action because he basically printed the truth.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But some of this stuff was out there. It wasn't a deep dig --

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Here's the other thing, President Trump has gone after a lot of people, and sometimes it's very uncouth, sometimes it's unforce, sometimes it's unattractive, but those people aren't facing 400 years in prison. So it's not just by virtue of the president being your enemy that land you in legal deep yogurt.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: It's the fact that he has done, reportedly, bad things to a bunch of people over a number of years. And some of these issues that he's facing are very, very serious. And Judge Napolitano laid that out earlier today on Fox News. This guy is facing some real time. So anyone who wants to be a high-profile ambulance chaser or, you know, just one of these celebrity lawyers, make sure that your past is a little squeakier than Avenatti did because he was not very careful.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And this looks like a case of straight greed, Juan. I mean, this is a guy with a Lamborghini, leases, you know, jewelry --

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Remember his dry cleaning bill?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A huge dry cleaning bill.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Multiple Rolex's and everything like that. It's like the Manafort situation. The guy with these $40,000 rugs and, you know, the cashmere socks and all that stuff.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He could have used a $40 grand rug.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sorry.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think they're less these days.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Nice plug.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, if he's guilty, he should go to jail. I mean, it's despicable behavior, especially on the part of someone that, you know, implicitly you've put great trust in your lawyer. But, you know, as I'm listening to this conversation, a couple of things, one, I think all of you are saying, well, because Avenatti was Trump's nemesis and now he's, you know, proven or not proven but allegedly a thief, oh, therefore, everything is cool. But, you know, the reality is --

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: No one said that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- that Trump lied about not knowing about a payment to silence a porn star that he was supposedly having sex with --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It was about Kavanaugh, nothing about Trump.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, forget Kavanaugh for a second. This is about Avenatti. And Avenatti is well known. This comes to your point, though, Greg. The reason Avenatti was on cable so much, and I think everybody here would say you've got to cover it, the president -- a man who becomes President of the United States is accused of having sex with a porn star, says it's not true, says he knows nothing about payments to that porn star, and then it's proven --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's about Kavanaugh when he came out, and he was milking Kavanaugh and try to ruin a guy's life. Not in a court of law.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. So you can say what you want about Kavanaugh --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'll just stick to why he was prominent to be in a position --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But, Juan, the last time -- what happened when the president lied about sex --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Hold on. I can't do two at once.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: OK, bed bugs are prominent but bed bugs are not a contender for the presidency. And that's unfortunately how a lot of people in the media framed Michael Avenatti.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, nobody -- look --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Don't smear bed bugs --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Subsequently, when he was so prominent because guess who was another prominent TV star? Oh, the president.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But that's no excuse for the Kavanaugh behavior. They let him destroy a man's live based on lies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Where's Julie Swetnick?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He made awful salacious allegations against Kavanaugh that were -- I don't know if proven wrong, but it didn't matter ultimately --

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: It weren't proven --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But with Trump the reason he became prominent was Stormy Daniels, and there's no getting away from that for you guys.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So Juan's argument is that Kavanaugh should thank Michael Avenatti.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: In many ways --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because guess what? Boy, Republicans --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Trump shouldn't be ashamed of Stormy Daniels. He paid her.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Avenatti didn't pay her. He took money from her.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Your Honor, I have nothing more to say. The client has spoken.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And then Stormy paid --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I've never denied it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Go figure. An NYU professor facing backlash for tweeting a fake quote by President Trump, Greg's monologue up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's a good day when one of the biggest news story is about a tweet that didn't happen, which you can add to the Trump-era wars that don't happen, or the Trump-era collusion that didn't happen either. Over the weekend, political science professor Ian Bremmer tweeted this quote attributed to President Trump, quote, Kim Jong-un is smarter and would make a better president than Sleepy Joe Biden. No joke. You could almost hear Trump saying that which is the problem. A bunch of hysterical anti-Trumpers believed it clogging twitter with breathless outrage for a day. Later Bremmer said it was a joke and he took it down. He apologized, problem solved. But here are a few lessons to turn this tiny, tiny story into a segment. If a parody doesn't offer a clue that it's a joke then it's not a parody, it's just misleading. Unlike most media which misleads on purpose by parodying actual journalism, and it's on Memorial Day weekend which notes the sacrifices of those who died for our country. One way to commemorate that is to make sure in the future that your country's blood is always treated as precious. So we must be doing somewhat better if our military foot print seems to be shrinking, and that many of the wars among adults are now over tweets. Two years ago we worried about real missiles coming from Kim, now it's about fake tweets heading toward him, that's progress for now anyway. He apologized promptly. I think the problem was it was plausible as he said.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Ian Bremmer is one of my dear friends. And so --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Globalist.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Amongst other things. He's not though, he's a big populist.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, is he?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't know. I'm not going to -- look, I read his book and I wanted to throw it against the wall because at the end he was for non- intervention. And you know --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You love war.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I believe in being the policemen of the world, I do.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But that was the thing is that -- the thing I've seen earlier in the day was President Trump's tweet.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: When I saw that tweet I was like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK, whatever. It's also -- it could go in my -- the book of -- fantasy book -- not a book of fantasy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You have a fantasy book?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Where you dressed up as a policeman?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This is going to be so good.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Remember the book I want to write called tweets I never sent.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, yeah, yeah, yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And also like twitter -- ah, twitter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, exactly. Jesse, I do feel safer now than I did with North Korea --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You do.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- even with the tweet. I do. And I think it's due to Trump's kind of nature of dealing with separating the person from the country. So he deals with the person which is what salesman do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. And I just think it's fine that these so-called experts keeps falling for hoaxes and then they blame the hoax instead of themselves.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: These people aren't as smart as they really are cracked up to be. Think about everybody that's an expert fell for Smollett, fell for the Russia collusion, fell for the dossier, fell for this. It's like -- it takes two days or a week of checking something and then you get to the bottom of it. But I don't even go on twitter anymore. I didn't go on twitter once this weekend --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wait.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- and I feel great. Then when they --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That is why we told you not to tweet anymore.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was your intervention?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Greg and I were trying to help you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was the first successful intervention that ever happened with me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's true. We took him in the greenroom and we've said --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I took twitter off Hannity's phone in 2015.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, it's right. You're the twitter cop. You're not just an interventionist foreign policy, you're an interventionist of social media. Juan, you've been a journalist for many years. Anything that seems too perfect never is, right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. It's almost more of the story. The rest of the story is as famously say. But I am a little surprise that this conversation in that last week wasn't it Trump supporters who put out was a distorted totally manipulated video of Nancy Pelosi looking like she was drunk, and people had to say, hey, this is not real.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: You don't need to distort those videos. They speak for themselves.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, no. If you slow them down, Kennedy, so that she sounds like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But they were obvious.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, they're obvious. Well, I think --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I noticed it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Democrats are complaining about propaganda. That's rich, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, that's rich. You're complaining about fake news?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. You can't --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: When people put out stuff -- because I think there's lot --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It happens all the time, Juan. It's just a video.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Distorted video.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's just a bunch of strange people in their basements making videos, and go around the internet and that's life

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. And then Greg says here on the show, oh, he feels safer when you have Trump repudiating what his own National Security Advisor John Bolton says, reputed what--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I thought you hated John Bolton.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I do not hate John Bolton.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Now, you're citing him as a--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. How about Shinzo Abe, the Prime Minister of Japan? All of them say, "Hey, Kim is a danger and Trump saying, no, he's all right. He didn't violate the deal".

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's playing chess and they're playing checkers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I never heard that before.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I just coined it right now.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: He's talking about Nixon's dog. God rests his soul.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, Kennedy thoughts, prayers?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: You're helping him Ian Bremmer is helping the President with tweets like this. And you never see the onion put up a funny headline and go, that's plausible.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: That's the problem. It shouldn't be plausible. If it's parody, if it's farce it should be so incredibly outrageous.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: But the problem is he puts something in the realm of plausibility just to make people like Ana Navarro and Ted Lieu - so they retweet it like, "See we told you, he has to go impeachable". Impeach, impeach, impeach. And you're only helping him because the biggest problem is that people will continue to divorce the President's actions and personality from his policies and result, and the more that happens "The Great Divorce" as C.S. Lewis called it. The better that President's chances are. And if you run around saying everything he does is just symptomatic of his insanity, at some point that starts to--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: When he says stuff like, "Oh, yes, Kim Jong-un is right, Joe Biden is a low IQ fool". You think, "What, that's our President?"

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's bridging differences, Juan, when you can agree with an adversary. Can I make a shout at?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: President Obama did the same thing about Trump when he was overstepping (ph).

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I want to make a shout out, though I've been ripping on CNN. I got a compliment Jake Tapper spends all Memorial Day basically just tweeting out memorials of fallen soldiers and that's the one area where you take the kind of the cemetery formality and he transferred it over to the superficiality of Twitter. So you can't just stay on Twitter and pretend that Memorial Day doesn't exist.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: One of his best - one of Jake Tapper's best tweets this weekend was, he was quoting a soldier who said "Be an American worth dying". Very inspirational.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I try that every day. All right coming up this. JAMIE SIMPSON, FOX45 WEATHERMAN: Just go back to the show. No, we're not going back to the show folks. This is a dangerous situation, OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: TV weatherman unleashes on viewers who'd rather watch "The Bachelorette" over his tornado warnings.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Tornadoes wreaking havoc in Ohio and amid the severe weather a local meteorologist was forced to scold angry viewers, they were griping about tornado warnings interrupting last night's episode of "The Bachelorette". Jamie Simpson was reporting on several twisters ripping through Ohio overnight killing at least one person. The powerful storms also left millions without power. But after Simpson broke into coverage, he got major, major backlash prompting this response.

utterances.speaker: SIMPSON
utterances.utterance: I was just checking social media; we have viewers complaining already, Just go back to the show. No, we're not going back to the show, folks. This is a dangerous situation, OK. Think about if this was your neighborhood. I'm sick and tired of people complaining about this. Our job here is to keep people safe, and that is what we're going to do. Some of you complained that this is all about my ego, stop. OK. Just stop right now. It's not. I'm done with you people, I really am, this is pathetic.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Simpson later apologized for his rant, but not for his message about safety. So Kennedy, I got to say, I don't think he was doing this for ratings. I think it really is a life-and-death situation.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: I don't think he necessarily makes the call single-handedly. He certainly can influence the call as to whether or not they dip in and out of programming. I haven't seen an interruption this egregious since the Knicks game was interrupted by the OJ chase. And I think they have to be incredibly mindful of what they're - it's very funny because, you want to keep people safe and you want to keep people alive and make sure that they have adequate information. But you really don't want to insult your audience.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait, you mean it was an insult not to interrupt, but the rant.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Yes, the rant. Look it up, Jamie, that's all I have to say.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. But Jesse I think it's kind of moronic to say, I'd rather watch "The Bachelorette" and endanger my life?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I mean, if it's the rose ceremony, that's not a good time to interrupt with storm coverage. People would rather die than find out who got the final rose, and that's fine. People are stupid, and they don't care about their fellow people in Ohio. But the guy - it was a little annoying. All he had to say was I'm sorry, we're getting a lot of comments from social media about interrupting The Bachelor, I'll make this as quick as possible. This is a life and death situation, that's all he had to say. He didn't need to get on his high horse.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Does this mean like when Shepard Smith comes on that we can just say, "Hey listen, you know what happened to that meteorologist in Ohio, can we do that?"

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, he got to you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Dana, I got to tell you, if there's a tornado near me, I'd be scared. I know flying--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So I grew up in a Eastern - rural Colorado and we had tornado warnings almost every day after school and my sister and I had taped a VCR - look it up folks - VCR and "The Grease" and then we would watch that movie all the time, but it had recorded during a tornado warning so there was like a big chunk of the movie that was missing. Even so we watched it every day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You just said thought there were tornadoes in "Grease".

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Every single time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But I also think this. A lot of people aren't watching your local stations anymore, right. You're watching on all sorts of different ways Netflix, Prime Video, whatever. I think that we should be allowed to have a technical device that you can suppress it at your own risk. If you don't want to know about tornado warnings, that's fine, you can right here it says I give up my right to see the thing and I'm going to watch "The Bachelorette". Let people make a choice.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, that's like that's like, Greg, when they tell people to evacuate and they're just yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I will just hang out here. I do find - I get the guys frustration. But if you go to the dump and you find trash it's not the dump's fault. Like, you know that you're going to get nothing but superficial takes on Twitter of people pissed off. So if you go there, it's kind of you're actively looking for that to get angry--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, why is he on social media?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: When there is a tornado.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It drives me crazy when people - they go Twitter and they make - they say something provocative and they get all this response. And then they get - then they're the victim. Like, "Oh, my god people are attacking me. Oh, please stop". It's like just get off there - get off there. But I do understand it's his vocation, he takes it seriously. But man when “The Five” is on and all of a sudden there's breaking news and worse - people--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Don't check your social media.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Don't check your social media, because people are angry.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, the thing - I must say - so like, I - my family goes down to the Outer Banks for summer vacation and they get hit by terrible hurricanes once in a blue moon. And then people - some people are like, "Nah man, I'm hanging out". And some people actually - I think you'd like this Kennedy, go surfing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There is a big wave. It's like, "Hey, what is wrong with you?"

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: No, surfers are the best storm chasers. They always go right in before the storm hits, because that's when the waves are perfect, because you have a nice onshore wind it's - where everything is --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Did anybody watch "The Bachelorette" last night?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Great surfing in Ohio, by the way.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Did anybody find out what happened?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Neither did I.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: It was very tragic. OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. Next up, the heat is on how a new study could give women the leverage to control the temperature, even in this studio.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Oh, it's cold in here. The debate over office temperatures is heating up and it's all thanks to a brand new study. It turns out women now have a valid reason to want to raise the temperature. The study found more ladies are more productive working when it's warmer, while men thrive in colder temps. And the battle for the thermostat - the Goldilocks temperature for both genders appears to be the mid-70s, which is also the Golden Age of dating. Jesse, do you agree with that - mid-70, 75, doesn't it sound a little bit warm?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm comfortable in most places. But I have a new strategy, which I'm going to employ, since we got new offices and we have a thermostat in our offices now.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Wow, oh, we do?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, we do.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Oh, I didn't see.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So our executive producers are female, Meghan, and she likes to come into my office and boss me around. She - next time she comes in I'm cranking that thing down to 54, 53, it's going to totally rattle her. She'll never be able to come and boss me around again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm going to freeze her out of this office, yes, she never want to come in.
